summary: Hairy cell leukemia (HCL) is an uncommon hematological malignancy characterized by the accumulation of abnormal B lymphocytes, often referred to as 'hairy cells' due to their cytoplasmic projections. These abnormal cells accumulate in the bone marrow, interfering with the production of normal blood cells, leading to pancytopenia. HCL typically has an indolent course, but patients frequently relapse. Despite this, with treatment, life expectancy is usually comparable to the general population.
causes: Genetic mutations (BRAF V600E mutation is a driver mutation in nearly all cases)
Possible correlation with herbicides (extrapolated from other chronic B-cell leukemias/lymphomas)
risk_factors: Older age (median age at diagnosis is 55-60 for classic HCL, over 70 for HCL-V)
Male sex (4:1 male to female ratio for classic HCL)
Farming and gardening (correlates with increased risk in some studies)
Exposure to herbicides (potential risk factor, though not specifically proven for HCL)
symptoms: Infections (due to low white blood cell count)
Fatigue (due to lack of red blood cells)
Easy bleeding (due to low platelet count)
Petechiae (tiny red dots under the skin due to bleeding)
diagnosis: Complete blood count (CBC) showing low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets
Blood smear examination (presence of hairy cells with characteristic projections)
Bone marrow biopsy (confirmation of HCL infiltration and absence of other diseases)
Flow cytometry (detection of specific cell surface markers like CD19, CD20, CD22, CD11c, CD25, CD103, FMC7)
Annexin A1 and BRAF V600E mutant protein testing
Imaging tests (e.g., CT scans for abdominal lymphadenopathy)
treatments: Watchful waiting (for asymptomatic patients with no significant cytopenia or organomegaly)
Rituximab (anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, often combined with purine analogs)
Splenectomy (may be used when other therapies fail and spleen has high disease burden)
Blood transfusions (for low red blood cells or platelets)
Filgrastim (to stimulate white blood cell production, routine use not recommended after cladribine)
Moxetumomab pasudotox (anti-CD22 immunotoxin, for relapsed disease)
Trametinib (MEK inhibitor, in combination with BRAF inhibitors)
Cobimetinib (MEK inhibitor, in combination with BRAF inhibitors)
related_genes: IGHV (immunoglobulin gene VH4-34 rearrangement is a poor prognostic factor)
